comments.body:
I guess that building from source is not an option for now, right?
I see that you are removing `git_bash.exe`. What is the reason for that? I thought that git needs git-bash to work properly on Windows. (Even if that is not true I am interested into having git bash there for teaching purposes :wink:)
I blatantly lifted this from conda-recipes. In this case, @msarahan would be the one to ask.

AFAICT building from source will become an option when @mingwandroid gets a bit further on packaging MSYS2 inside conda.  I don't know if anyone has succeeded at building git with a native Windows toolchain (I couldn't find any examples).

The EXEs that are removed are ones that live in the root of that extracted package.  There are equivalents in bin that are not deleted.  There's both git-bash and bash (which I think do the same thing?)

I have used an earlier version of this recipe to teach a SWC class.  It worked very well - especially with the shortcut that this recipe installs.  It actually only had problems on Mac (due to certificates not being found.)  I did fix that - I'll be sure to merge those changes here.  The fix was basically to download certs from cURL's site and put them in the correct place, then tell git where to find them.

> I have used an earlier version of this recipe to teach a SWC class

Aha! You answered my question. Thanks!
I'd also like to add that I almost always use git inside cmd.exe, and haven't encountered any problem so far :-)
Tab completion works for branch names in git bash but not in cmd using bash.  I also use them both, though.
